title: 112_hr6037
content: The Act titled "Small Business Lending for Jobs Act of 2012" focuses on credit availability. The Federal banking agencies are mandated to focus on fostering credit availability in a safe manner and assisting insured depository institutions in providing credit responsibly to encourage business development and employment. The Federal banking agencies are prohibited from pressuring insured depository institutions to provide specific types of credit or terms. Within 120 days of the enactment of the Act, each agency must submit a report to Congress outlining how they will modify rules and policies to align with the new mission, with all modifications in effect within 180 days. Each Federal banking agency must issue a report to Congress within 360 days of the Act's enactment, and annually thereafter, assessing how their policies support credit availability to insured depository institution customers in a safe manner. The Credit Availability Council is established, consisting of the head of each Federal banking agency or a designee. The council will assess the agency's progress in implementing its modified mission, evaluate performance, and determine corrective measures for deficiencies. The Credit Availability Council, comprised of the head of each Federal banking agency or a designee, coordinates efforts to foster credit availability in a safe and sound manner and assist insured depository institutions in providing responsible credit to encourage business development and employment. The term "Federal banking agency" includes the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The Credit Availability Council, consisting of the heads of Federal banking agencies or their designees, coordinates efforts to promote credit availability in a safe manner. The term "Federal banking agency" includes the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System, the Bureau of Consumer Financial Protection, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, and the National Credit Union Administration. An insured depository institution is defined as an insured depository institution under the Federal Deposit Insurance Act and an insured credit union under the Federal Credit Union Act. SEC. 3. COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE LOAN LOSS AMORTIZATION. An insured depository institution with assets under $10,000,000,000 can choose to amortize losses on commercial real estate loans or other real estate owned over a 7-year period. This provision applies to losses occurring after January 1, 2007, and before the end of a 2-year period from the enactment of the Act. An insured depository institution can choose to amortize losses on real estate over a 7-year period. They must disclose the difference in capital on financial reports and make a one-time adjustment for prior losses. The term "insured depository institution" is defined under the Federal Deposit Insurance Act. The term "other real estate owned" is defined under the Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 4. INCLUSION OF LOAN LOSS RESERVES IN COMPUTATION OF CAPITAL RESERVES. The Federal banking agencies will issue regulations allowing insured depository institutions to include all loan and lease loss reserves in their capital calculations for risk-based requirements, except for classified losses. Regulations must be issued within 120 days of the enactment of the Act, and agencies must report to Congress annually on this matter. The Federal banking agency will report to Congress on the implementation and impact of provisions related to loan and lease losses, including their effect on lending availability and the safety of insured depository institutions. The term "allowance for loan and lease losses" refers to general valuation allowances established to absorb losses on loans and lease financing receivables, excluding allocated transfer risk. The term "lease losses" excludes allocated transfer risk reserves and specific reserves against identified losses. The term "appropriate Federal banking agencies" and "insured depository institution" have specific meanings under relevant sections of the Federal Deposit Insurance Act.
